fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \hat {C} be a presheaf category. Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {\Omega } Set be the sieve functor, which sends an object x to the set of sieves on x, and a map y\xrightarrow {f}x to its action on sieves by restriction: (\Omega f)(S) = \{g: fg\in S\}. Let *\xhookrightarrow {\top } \Omega (where * is the constant functor at the singleton) identify for each x\in C the maximal sieve. Then \top is a subobject classifier in \hat {C}.

Let Q\hookrightarrow P be a subobject in \hat {C}. We need to define the classifying natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\chi _Q}\Omega ; we work in components. At an object x\in C, this map must send an element p\in Px to a sieve on x; we choose the sieve (\chi _Q)_x(p) = \{z\xrightarrow {f} x\in C: p|_f \in Qz\}. In other words, this sieve consists of those maps which restrict p to an element of Q.

Next, to show that it is a pullback, it suffices to show that it is a pullback at each x\in C, and by the construction of limits in Set, it suffices to show that (\chi _Q)_x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. The backwards direction is already done; conversely, if it is the maximal sieve, then we obtain the result by observing that 1_x\in (\chi _Q)_x(p) and applying the definition of \chi _Q.

Finally, to show uniqueness, suppose that we have another natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\theta } \Omega . By the above argument, for the square to be a pullback, we must have that \theta _x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. Now further, given z\xrightarrow {f} x and applying the same fact at z, we must have that p|_f\in Qz if and only if \theta _z(p|_f) is the maximal sieve. By naturality of \theta at a map f, we have that \theta _z(p|_f) = \Omega f(\theta _x(p)), which by definition of \Omega is the maximal sieve if and only if f\in \theta _x(p). As a consequence, if the square is a pullback, we must have that f\in \theta _x(p) if and only if p|_f\in Qz, yielding exactly the definition of \chi _Q above.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sheaves in geometry and logic
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @book{maclane-moerdijk-1994, title = {Sheaves in Geometry and Logic: A First Introduction to Topos Theory}, author = {MacLane, S. and Moerdijk, I.}, isbn = {9781461209270}, doi = {10.1007/978-1-4612-0927-0} lccn = {91033709}, series = {Universitext}, url = {https://books.google.com/books?id=LZWLBAAAQBAJ}, year = {1994}, publisher = {Springer New York}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We dedicate this book to the memory of J. Frank Adams. His clear insights have inspired many mathematicians, including both of us. In January 1989, when the first draft of our book had been completed, we heard the sad news of his untimely death. This has cast a shadow on our subsequent work. Our views of topos theory, as presented here, have been shaped by continued study, by conferences, and by many personal contacts with friends and colleagues-including especially O. Bruno, P. Freyd, J.M.E. Hyland, P.T. Johnstone, A. Joyal, A. Kock, F.W. Lawvere, G.E. Reyes, R Solovay, R Swan, RW. Thomason, M. Tierney, and G.C. Wraith. Our presentation combines ideas and results from these people and from many others, but we have not endeavored to specify the various original sources. Moreover, a number of people have assisted in our work by pro viding helpful comments on portions of the manuscript. In this respect, we extend our hearty thanks in particular to P. Corazza, K. Edwards, J. Greenlees, G. Janelidze, G. Lewis, and S. Schanuel.
The singleton set * is the terminal object in Set. Explicitly, it is the set with one element.
The maximal sieve on an object x is the sieve consisting of all arrows with codomain x; equivalently, the sieve associated to the contravariant hom-functor.

Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {P} Set be a presheaf, y\xrightarrow {f} x\in C a map, and p\in Px an element. Then the restriction of p along f, or the pullback of p along f, is p|_f = Pf(p). The restriction maps of P are just the induced set-functions Pf for each morphism f.

A sieve is a subfunctor of a contravariant hom-functor. Explicitly, a sieve S on x\in C consists of a collection of maps with codomain x that is closed under precomposition, i.e. if z\xrightarrow {f}x\in S and z'\xrightarrow {g} z is any map, then fh\in S.

fr:title.text: Limits and colimits in functor categories are computed pointwise

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits and colimits in functor categories are computed pointwise

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a small category. Then where \operatorname *{obj} C is the discrete category of objects, the forgetful functor C^A\to C^{\operatorname *{obj} A} strictly creates all limits and colimits in C. For each a\in A, the evaluation at a functor C^A\to C preserves all limits and colimits which exist in C.

Let c be an object in a category C, and let J be any category. The constant functor at c is the functor J\xrightarrow {c} C that sends every object of J to c and every morphism of J to the identity 1_c.

The constant functors induce a functor C\xrightarrow {\Delta } J^C to the functor category which sends each object of C to the corresponding constant functor and each morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y to the natural transformation with components \alpha _j = f for each j\in J.

fr:title.text: Set is complete â€º construction of limits in Set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set is complete â€º construction of limits in Set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
A pullback is a limit of a diagram of shape \bullet \to \bullet \leftarrow \bullet .
The symbol \lrcorner in the previous diagram denotes that the square is a pullback.
A presheaf on a category C is a contravariant functor C^\text {op}\to Set. The presheaf category \hat {C} is the functor category Set^{C^\text {op}} of presheaves on C.

A natural transformation F\xrightarrow {\alpha } G between functors C\xrightarrow {F,G} D consists of, for every object x\in C, a morphism \alpha _x: Fx\to Gx (the components) such that, for every morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y in C, the following diagram commutes:
